Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: AVATOL - Next Generation Phenomics for the Tree of Life
Award.AbstractNarration:
Darwin's theory of evolution explained that millions of species are related, and dealt biologists and paleontologists the enormous challenge of discovering the branching pattern of the Tree of Life. Work on this great challenge is producing a map of species-relatedness through Earth history, and answering questions such as "what is the closest relative of a species?" and "what species make important products?" To do this scientists draw on all heritable features, including genotypes (e.g., DNA) and phenotypes (e.g., anatomy). Studying phenotypes, however, has remained complicated and slow, because it has not been revolutionized by computer science and engineering innovations.

A team of biologists, computer scientists, and paleontologists will extend and adapt methods from computer vision, machine learning, crowd-sourcing and natural language processing to enable rapid and automated study of phenotypes for the Tree of Life on a vast scale. The three-year goal is to release large phenomic datasets built using new methods, and to provide the public and scientific community with tools for future work. Planned is the training of teachers and students (kindergarten - postdoctoral levels) and the engagement of "citizen scien-tists." Enormous phenomic datasets, many with images, will fill an important public interest in biodiversity and the fossil record.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The task the University of Arizona team tackled in this project is automatic phenotype character extraction from text descriptions. We have accomplished the following

(1) We developed the first web application, Explorer of Taxon Concepts (ETC: http://etc.sbs.arizona.edu/etcsite/start.html), for extracting phenotype characters from taxonomic descriptions of a variety of taxon groups, ranging from plants to micro-organisms. We developed MicroPIE (now is part of ETC toolkit) that extracts over 40 phenotype characters (e.g., growth temperature, like oxygen or not) from taxonomic descriptions of microbial organisms. Both tools compile extracted characters into a taxon-character matrix format, which is a common data format for systematic research. The ETC site consists of 5 tools that can be used as a pipeline, performing the task of character extraction from text, creating a domain ontology, generating a taxon-character matrix, generating an interactive identification tool (allowing polymorphic characters), and aligning taxon concepts using RCC-5 logic. These tools can also be used as individual tools, if appropriate input is given. We evaluated and reported system performance in several peer-reviewed journal publications. These tools, available on the Web and accessible to the public free of charge,  enable biologists or bioinformaticians to evaluate the information extraction performance on the taxon groups of their interests. ETC has been used by other projects to compile data layers for flagellate plants, to collect needed character data for research, and to build new digital presence of large floras, for example, Flora of North America. 

In this project, we also evaluated machine learning algorithms including Support Vector Machines, Conditional Random Field, and Long Short-Term Memory Deep Neural Net on the task of extracting challenging microbial phenotype characters. Findings from our evaluation of various algorithms and various features (lexical, syntactic, and semantic) will be helpful for the Named Entity Recognition research community to understand the characteristics of this task and to inform the development of more robust and accurate extractor.

Along with the algorithm and software development, we have also built a large categorical glossary covering the majority volumes of Flora of North America and Flora of China, following a consensus building procedure initized by us and supported by OTO (Ontology Term Organizer, another software tool we developed in an earlier NSF-funded project). We participated in the building of a rich ontology,  MicroO, for micro-organism. Phenotype terminology usage in systematic biology is very diverse. Exposing terminology variations is the first necessary step to integrating knowledge from different branches of systematic biology, and creating ontology that can be used by biologists in their writing practice is the next.  Our next project will focus on the 2nd goal. 

Building ground-truth data set for information extraction task is time consuming. All the datasets built in this project are made public on our github site, where all our software source code  (including documentation) and glossaries can also be found: http://github.com/biosemantic. We belief in Open and Verifiable Science. By making our research data accessible to experts and the public, they can access, verify, and build upon our work using these materials.
